comments.commentBody: You can also measure the likelihood that you are going to get good financial analysis by teachers when you look at the horrid quality of economics and finance classes taught at the high school level. Most school systems do not even teach basic finance and whenever I suggest that they should consider this I am told privately that one of the concerns is that what they teach the students will be woefully different from the student's parents do in real life and the school doesn't want to create conflict!

What I hear most often is that teachers are already so overwhelmed by the amount of things they must teach -- so as to teach to the various tests that are now part of the system -- that there isn't room for things like personal finance. (That said, it amazes me that in places where there is personal finance instruction, it's rarely about the college financing/debt system -- something that teenagers could actually put to work right away. It would take about 12 hours to explain it all, alas -- a whole semester of 1 hour per week classes.)
Trump has secret plans, but he can't trust his incompetent generals with them.
Maybe we could get Trump and Kim to go at it mano a mano, without incompetent generals. Televise it, and then collapse the arena on both of them.

Of course - Trump wants a Yuuge increase in military spending and the Times provides him with a bogeyman. Even the most distracted of North Korean leadership knows that any use of these things is instant national suicide.

It never ever ends - the wheels on the bus go round and round....

Plennnie it must be nice sitting in Switzerland, a country with no military or defense mechanisms, throwing stones at the world's protector.  Don't think for a moment that Kim Jong-un wouldn't flip that switch.  I'm sure you're aware that he just had is half brother killed last week, his uncle last year and hundreds of other people since he came into power.  He'll use his nuclear capability to hold the rest of the world hostage if we don't step in and stop him.
Perhaps we need to spend a little more time on what is happening in the rest of the world.  Thank you for this wrenching article.
We should not  expect the West to step in; particularly not the isolationist Trump's America.

There is a need for teachers to take the time to understand what their district offers and what is available in the private sector. With low cost index funds and ETFs available in many lower cost brokerage options the teachers have options IF (a) they take the time to enroll and (b) have the discipline not to raid these personal funds prior to retirement. The 403(b) penalties for early withdrawal discourage spending funds prior to retirement in exchange ( in theory) for tax deferral; however ETFs and index funds are extremely tax efficient without the tax wrapper induced fees that come with annuities.
Now, their union leaders won't be going to lunch with 403(b) annuity salesman under this arrangement and there is a little "work" to be done individually to evaluate the right fund company ( start with Vanguard, Schwarz and Fidelity and frankly any of those are probably lower cost providers than the 493(b) option and invest some time.
Frankly, with the exception of department heads and administrators most of the people you are looking to help have 2 1/2 months every summer to work on personal non-school related issues so they should take a few days and invest in their own future as opposed to hoping that their union representative's will have their best interests at heart!

2 1/2 months off every summer that are without pay, I might add. And that is if one is fortunate enough to not need to teach summer school or get a temporary position to supplement the $25,000 a year starting salary (e.g. Arizona) or even $37,000 (e.g. California) offered by your district.

This is an ad for polyamory.

While it's great the 2 of them were so devoted, note that when she dies, this great guy will be left without a mate. Had they been poly, this would not have happened (ie, he would have another/more than one other woman to be with after she died). And had she had multiple partners, she would not be facing death with just one partner by her side, but could have had 3 or 4. That would have been better for everyone.

The more I read such heartbreaking stories, the more certain I am that polyamory is the way to go. It is much more practical and offers much more support to people than does monogamy.
Nice empathy try but I think you failed. Think anyone wants to hear it?
Delude yourself all you wish.

Dearest Amy,
Thank you for your beautiful and moving essay. Amy comes from the word ami which means friend in French. You are your husband's best friend and a friend to all those people who were fortunate enough to read your essay in the NY Times.
I am so glad you had 26 years of bliss and more with Jason and that you have the kind of wise and generous heart to wish him more of the same with someone else after you are gone.
I am sure that Jason is one of the most fortunate men in America. What a Valentine!!

Amy,

Jason may not be for me.
I've met my version of j,
but I am no longer that version of me.

Thank you ❤️ ~ M
Your words have been love I've shared with my children since we found Little Pea. Thank you!

Do you know the beautiful poem written by Anne Morrow Lindbergh after the death of her first son?  I won't repeat it in its entirety, but the ending is enough...."There is no harvest for the heart alone....the seed of love must be eternally resown".
Best and true comment...

Ryan -
There ARE good women out there in the world - and one will find you when you least expect it. My Valentina found me at 41 (the length of my bachelorhood was my own fault - H-D bikes & long whiskers) but she made me want to be whatever made her happy.
You know what you want, and all the advice I can give is "prepare yourself for what you want, so you will be ready when she arrives".
All Good Things,
Jersey Danny
Alpine, NJ

Having known Gilda Radner peripherally (member of SNL band) and also having a close friend and an aunt survive Ovarian cancer, and a cousin survive Breast cancer - - PLEASE !! EARLY DETECTION ! ! and a second opinion if you have ANY doubts!
Those who share love with you are worth every effort ! !

All Good Things,
Jersey Danny

What a gracious offer.  He sounds like quite a catch.  I'm going to turn you down because no woman will ever match you.  You are the love of his life and always will be.  Your wit and bravery are inspiring. Peace to you and your family.

Mud-slinging, labeling, demonizing and using stereotypes are so easy. It requires much less effort than sincerely trying to understand other people's true perspectives and motivations. Neither governor Walker's write-up, nor the comments against it, do anything to help us recover as a country; by continuing to blame "liberals” or “republicans” we strengthen and perpetuate our divide and adversarial relationship. Ideas and actions should be evaluated on their merits and not simply based on their source.  I expect politicians and every other person who has the ability to reach a wide audience to explain their perspectives evenhandedly, sharing both the benefits and drawbacks. In my own work, I am skeptical of new ideas that are put forth with no down sides; everything has a down side, and every option requires trade-offs. American’s from every political party should demand from their leaders and their peers that they explain these trade-offs and the data they are based on, so we can get our focus back on ideas for solving problems instead of tearing each other down.

In my humble opinion the states have become an anachronism and it's time to turn this 18th century collection of provincial political entities into a unified national state more suitable to the needs of a 21st century people. From the very beginnings of the US it was the federal constitution which guaranteed us the freedoms that many of the individual states would deny us  today if they could get away with it.

Ah, if only life were so simple!  What might be considered is jettisoning 18th and 19th century political borders within the United States so there is some rough correspondence between economic regions and governmental ones.  Truth is, the United States is part of the reshaping of the world, and that reshaping is reducing the importance "Western civilization" achieved owing to European exploitation of the Western hemisphere.  Well, China and India are regaining the importance that had more than 500 years age, and the adjustment is painful for "the West."

Scott Walker can tout his achievements all he wants but the constant draining of education funds to our universities has made the state less attractive to high tech businesses. His stubborn refusal to acknowledge the reality of man made climate change has him gutting the Department of Natural Resources and making permits for corporate farms that pose a danger to our drinking water. Worse, our highways are so bad now that some towns are replacing paved roads with gravel ones. This because our governor refuses to raise the gas tax or levy higher fees.
I believe we need a leaner government and less regulations. But blindly following the Koch Party Line will not improve it. Instead we will have constant swinging from left to right and a fed up citizenry with nothing being accomplished.

Ahh, the old and worn out battle cry for "states rights" or "state control". All Mr. Walker is proposing is rather than the Federal Government kick many of the unwashed rank and file citizen's programs to the curb, let the states do the dirty work.
My state has been clamoring for years about that cursed EPA initiatives to clean up our extremely dirty air by enforcing and enacting "job killing rules" which is GOP speak is "we need to allow businesses to pollute as much as they need in order to make a profit".
Return to "state management" which, in many "red" states means elimination of programs for equal pay, workplace safety and harassment, elimination or curtailing of social programs.
As I read this op-ed, I see much self-aggrandizement as we see from our apprentice President, so, it makes me question, what is the real story, Mr. Walker-where your programs toxic for many of the resident to the benefit of the few "connected" persons and businesses?

Mr. Walker as one of the members of the original tea party , it's very shameful on your part to advise the current members of congress to stand strong against all these protests by the really concerned citizens of this country who see no future.

To you and many others in your party Trump might look like a savior or a messiah.

But to the Democrats like us, he's nothing but a crook and a con man and a snake oil salesman who won the election only with the help of Putin and the Russian intelligence officials who hacked Hillary's computer to the last private email she wrote where she wrote to her daughter Chelsea, "I love you."

Now to call these protesters with name calling and saying their protests at all the Republican town hall meetings will fizzle out just like the protests in your Wisconsin state Capitol fizzled out in 2011, is nothing but an Utopian dream.

These protests will not die out until Trump resigns.

Because what brought you here and many other candidates who won with the help of millions of protesters are quite similar to what the current protests are.

Our Democratic congress members lost their seats then only because of very racist vitriol that you were engaged in to reverse the gains that the Democrats made with the help of the wave that was created after the election of our country's history making event when a black man called Mr. Barack Obama was elected the first colored president of this great country of 300+ years and with 350+ millions of Americans.

Some matters are inherently cross-state. E.g. the environment: if your landlocked state contributes to global warming, my coastal state will suffer flooding. Or if your state's lax gun laws enable trafficking of guns to my state.

If you can make an evidence-based case that your state policy doesn't significantly affect my state, then fine. My reaction to this election was, frankly, this: if voters in Kansas don't care if their poor or sick suffer, I'm done caring more than they do. I'm just done.

Right on the mark. A combination of big money and rigging elections has given us a raft of GOP politicians whose main goal is upward redistribution of wealth. Walker's claim that the GOP is all about states rights is pure bunk. States rights and local control are invoked whenever convenient, scrapped when the locals do something the servants of the wealthy deplore, such as raise the minimum wage or impose a family leave policy. Taking health care, one shortcoming of the ACA was that it left too much to the states, where Republican governors and legislatures could cripple it and then blame the Democrats. Walker may be an honest politician in the sense that he stays bought, but otherwise he's the poster child for just what this country does not need. A national election demonstrated that quite clearly, as he was the first to drop out of the presidential contest; no wonder he prefers state-level politics.

No one voted based on a choice between their dollar going "to your local school" or "caring for the needy in your community" or "to Washington." I don't recall locally administered services and compassion being the highlight of the Republican campaign. The idea that returning authority to the states for health care is somehow going to adequately replace Obamacare would be joke, if it weren't so unhealthy for the suckers who believed it. People voted on the myth that there were going to keep significantly more of their dollars to themselves, mostly by avoiding giving them to the vast undeserving - allegedly for services received by the undocumented immigrants from whom they were so mortally threatened and also the undeserving around the world. And of course some of the most wealthy of our citizens funded the whole campaign and voted on the truth that they would keep every possible penny all for themselves. Their anti-tax, pro-greed groups oppose state and local programs as strenuously as federal ones. Just like you.
